Issues.Title: fix(router): Apply named outlets to children of empty paths not appearing in the URL
Issues.Body:
Empty path routes are effectively 'passthrough' routes that do not appear in the URL. When these exist in the route tree, we do not want to apply named outlet commands to that tree location. Instead, we skip past this location in the tree, effectively squashing/removing this passthrough route from the tree.

fixes #50356
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(router): Apply named outlets to children of empty paths not appearing in the URL" (#51292)

Issues.Title: Massive overhead with flushAnimations even with NoopAnimationsModule on Universal
Issues.Body: ### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? animations ### Is this a regression? No ### Description When using the NoopAnimationsModule on Universal, my flame chart looks like this: Note the massive overhead on the flushAnimations. I wrote a monkey patch just to test: ``` let patched = true; if (!patched) { const originalFlush = ɵAnimationEngine.prototype.flush; ɵAnimationEngine.prototype.flush = function(...args: any[]): any {}; patched = true; } ``` The page still renders on Universal - to be honest I didn't see any differences with JS disabled - but this time the burndown chart looks like this: The render completes in about half the time, and most of that time is idle time (waiting for API / async operations to complete). I would say it's possibly around a 10x difference in our case. Is this normal behaviour, or perhaps something that might be wrong with the project? ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug _No response_ ### Please provide the exception or error you saw ```true No error ``` ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular CLI: 15.2.9 Node: 18.16.1 Package Manager: yarn 1.22.19 OS: darwin arm64 Angular: 15.2.9 ... animations, cdk, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core ... forms, localize, material, platform-browser ... platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server, router ... youtube-player Package Version --------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.1502.9 @angular-devkit/build-angular 15.2.9 @angular-devkit/core 15.2.9 @angular-devkit/schematics 13.3.11 @angular/flex-layout 14.0.0-beta.41 @angular/google-maps 13.2.6 @nguniversal/builders 15.2.0 @nguniversal/express-engine 14.2.3 @schematics/angular 15.2.9 rxjs 7.8.0 typescript 4.8.4 webpack 5.74.0 ``` ### Anything else? _No response_

Issues.Title: feat(core): add `setFakeBaseSystemTime()` to public API
Issues.Body:
Allows to specify a fake time in fakeAsync tests. Similar to using Jasmines "Clock" with a mockDate, which cannot be used in fakeAsync tests.

## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?
<!-- Please describe the current behavior that you are modifying, or link to a relevant issue. -->
If you want to specify a fake "now" time in your tests, you need to use [Jasmines "Clock" feature](https://jasmine.github.io/api/5.1/Clock) with a mockDate. This does not work in fakeAsync tests. You need to remove fakeAsync from your test and use `jasmine.clock().tick()` instead of the usual `tick()`.

In our project we use page objects to interact with our components. They rely on being used in fakeAsync tests, because their methods call the `tick()` function. That means, currently we cannot use them in combination with a fake time.

Issue Number: N/A


## What is the new behavior?

In a fakeAsync test, you can specify a fake "now" time by calling `setFakeBaseSystemTime()`.


## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(core): add `setFakeBaseSystemTime()` to public API" (#51286)

Issues.Title: use useFactory or analog for every inject
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core

### Description

If we use `{ provide: MyService, useFactory: () => new MyService() }` then `new MyService()` is executed once per module. It would be nice to have a `useFactoryPerInject` that runs `new MyService()` for each injection.

This is most often needed to move unsubscribe logic from the component to the service injected into the component. So we can use `DestroyRef` for our myService instance within the instance itself, or (possibly) use `takeUntilDestroyed` at this place. Of course whole logic except unsubscription logic of our service will be static.

### Proposed solution

Use `{ provide: MyService, useFactoryPerInject: () => new MyService() }` inside providers (e.g. module providers)
or `@Injectable({provideIn:  'elementInjector'})` as service decorator.

### Alternatives considered

There are no alternatives, unfortunately. The only solution is to create instances by `providers: [MyService]` for each component, but this we need to do it for the Application layer.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "use useFactory or analog for every inject" (#51282)

Issues.Title: effect() created in toObservable() keeps watching the signal when using in Guards
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When using toObservable() in guards, the effect() created internally to watch for the value of the signal keeps active after the observable has completed and the guard resolved. What is worst, is that after navigating to other pages that require the same guard, a new effect may be created, leading to memory leaks.

In internal code of toObservable() the is a watcher const that store the effect(), and it gets destroyed only if the injector is detroyed too, but it seems not to be the case in guards.

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

https://codesandbox.io/p/sandbox/boring-morning-v8krxs?file=%2Fsrc%2Fapp%2Faccess.guard.ts%3A15%2C48

### Please provide the exception or error you saw
The console log keeps track of all effect() triggering, and when changing pages the new effects accumulate gradually. The cumulative effect may be seen after switching pages a few times, and then switching the auth status. As the signal changes, all the effect() are executed together.


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.1.6
Node: 20.4.0 (Unsupported)
Package Manager: npm 9.8.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 16.1.7
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1601.6
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.1.6
@angular-devkit/core            16.1.6
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.1.6
@angular/cli                    16.1.6
@schematics/angular             16.1.6
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.1.6
zone.js                         0.13.1
```


### Anything else?

The solution may be that, after the observable has completed, the effect() should be destroyed, even if the injector context is still active, as the is no need to keep watching the signal. This could be acomplished by adding a pipe with a finalize operator that destroys the watcher.

`
return subject.asObservable().pipe(finalize(watcher.destroy));
`

#51279
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "effect() created in toObservable() keeps watching the signal when using in Guards " (#51280)

Issues.Title: fix(core): toObservable() watcher keeps active upon observable completion
Issues.Body:
When the observable is completed or finished, but the injector keeps active (Like when calling toObservable() in guards), the effect watcher remains unnecessarily active. Currently, the code is set up to destroy the watcher only when the injector context is destroyed, but that already is the default behavior of signals and effects. Watcher should be destroyed when the observable is marked as complete instead of, because after that there is no reason to keep watching the orginal signal.

#51280

What kind of change does this PR introduce?

Issues.Title: Wrong explanation in @Self() resolution modifiers
Issues.Body:
### Wrong explanation

https://angular.io/guide/hierarchical-dependency-injection at Self() section.

It says _@Self() tells the injector to stop searching in the current host element._

I think its wrong because @self() decorator is injecting only if it is available in the current host element. 

It should be like _'tells the injector to  only search in the current host element'_


![image](https://github.com/angular/angular/assets/72804437/69c45afa-6da3-4f97-92ec-3a4c04625d65)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Wrong explanation in @Self() resolution modifiers " (#51278)

Issues.Title: Package Style with Directives
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

core, elements

### Description

It would be nice to have the ability to package style with `@Directives` as well as with `@Components`.

We can create directives that alter the structure of components and sometimes we use CSS as part of the alteration ...

### Proposed solution

Add something to `@Directives` that allows the style to be packaged with the directive ...

### Alternatives considered

Currently I just put styles associated with directives in the structure mixin for the theme...like this....

```
@mixin structure($theme) {
    .el-RoundedSelect
        .mat-mdc-form-field-flex
        .mdc-notched-outline
        .mdc-notched-outline__notch
        label.mdc-floating-label--float-above {
        top: 28px !important;
    }    
}
```

As you can see it does not really depend on the theme, but it just ended up being a logical place to put it since directives can't include the style directly ...
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Package Style with Directives" (#51275)

Issues.Title: Deferred followup refactors
Issues.Body:
A couple of refactors around `defer` that we had discussed before plus one bug fix I found along the way. Includes the following changes:

### refactor(compiler): store deferred triggers as a map
Stores the `deferred` block triggers as a map instead of an array, because triggers can't be duplicated and because having to search through an array will be inconvenient later on.

I've also added a `DeferredBlock.visitAll` method to deduplicate the logic from the various visitor implementations.

### refactor(compiler): add more deferred validations
Adds validations for the following invalid deferred block structures:
* Duplicated triggers.
* Multiple `minimum` parameters on `placeholder` and `loading` blocks.
* Multiple `after` parameters on `loading` blocks.

### refactor(compiler): correctly identify lazy directives and pipes used after a nested defer block
Fixes that if a directive/pipe is used after a nested `defer` block, we weren't tracking it as lazy anymore. This was due to the fact that we were resetting the `isInDeferBlock` to false every time instead of the previous value.

Issues.Title: Example code for injection token is misleading/does not work this way
Issues.Body:
### Describe the problem that you experienced

The [documentation on `InjectionToken`](https://angular.io/api/core/InjectionToken) suggests that this code snippet will work in a meaningful way:

```typescript
interface MyInterface {...}
const myInterface = injector.get(new InjectionToken<MyInterface>('SomeToken'));
```

However, trying this shows that it cannot work: If the `InjectionToken` _instance_ passed to `injector.get` is not the same as the one specified in the provider, Angular will throw a `NullInjectorException`.

Therefore, passing a newly constructed `InjectionToken` instance to `injector.get` should never make any sense, as it will invariably lead to the described exception. At least, this seems to be the case when the token is typed to a type that does not have a runtime representation, such as an interface - but note that precisely this case is what the example, and the text blocks around it, are all about.

### Enter the URL of the topic with the problem

https://angular.io/api/core/InjectionToken

### Describe what you were looking for in the documentation

I am in a situation where I need to provide a generically typed interface implementation on one side, and inject this very interface, generically typed, on the other side (e.g. of a component outlet).

To get the injection token with the correct type, I had a factory object generate the `InjectionToken` instance with the correct type parameter from a function in both the provider and the injection call.

I was looking for confirmation that this can work, and the example showing that I can pass a newly instantiated `InjectionToken` to `injector.get` seemed to confirm this.

### Describe the actions that led you to experience the problem

I ran a little experiment, by declaring a provider, passing it to a component outlet, and trying to inject that provided value.

When I called the `InjectionToken` constructor (e.g. like this: `new InjectionToken<ITestInfo>('test-info')`, with `ITestInfo` being a commonly accessible interface) both in the provider and the inject call (with the same type argument and desc value), I would get a `NullInjectorException`.

When I used one and the same `InjectionToken` in both places, on the other hand, this worked without errors.

### Describe what you want to experience that would fix the problem

- A clear statement that, when typing the injection token to an interface type (or presumably, at least any type without a runtime representation), using the same _instance_ of `InjectionToken` in both provider and injection call is crucial.
- A change of the misleading example to make clear that the same _instance_ of `InjectionToken` has to be passed to `injector.get` as what was used to provide the value.

### Add a screenshot if that helps illustrate the problem

_No response_

### If this problem caused an exception or error, please paste it here

```true
ERROR NullInjectorError: R3InjectorError(ModulesExampleTopicOneModule)[InjectionToken test-info -> InjectionToken test-info -> InjectionToken test-info]: 
  NullInjectorError: No provider for InjectionToken test-info!
```
```


### If the problem is browser-specific, please specify the device, OS, browser, and version

_No response_

### Provide any additional information here in as much as detail as you can

_No response_

Issues.Title: Add a `provideTranslation` function to the framework (plus add a guideline to create `withXxx` features from third-party libs like ngx-translate
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

localize

### Description

With a colleague of mine, we've made a provideTranslation function today that can be used like this
```ts
...
providers: [
    ...
    provideTranslation('fr-FR', localFr)
]
```
This function would do two main things:
- set the `LOCAL_ID` to the locale passed as arg
- `registerLocaleData` within an APP_INITIALIZER, with the localeData passed as an argument

> It's the very first step, we could probably improve it a lot by providing more options like an autoDetect option, or even a factory that should return languages based on some logic or anything else I can't think of right now.

In addition, we've added rest arguments that take a `translationFeatures` (not sure about the name yet) that could be used by any third-party libraries to provide a way to configure their features.
As we use ngx-translate, we've made a `withNgxTranslate(...)` function that can be used like this:
```ts
...
providers: [
    ...
    provideTranslation('fr-FR', localFr, withNgxTranslate(
        { suffix: './assets/i18n', prefix: '.json', namespace: 'app' },
        { ... }
    ))
]
```
> I'm not sure yet if it could be implemented like this today in the framework but for every apps we have in our organization, that's what we'd currently use. If we moved to transloco, we would then implement a `withTransloco` function to work the same way.

If things like this could be added to the framework, I think it'd be a great addition and it could provide a sort of _guideline_ for third-party libs maker (just like there is a guideline from RxJS to create your custom operators)

> I've never used the i18n package made by angular so, as we currently made it, it may be incomplete or not adapted yet but, with the help of the community we could finally have an easy way to set up translations in our apps

> If this feature request harvests all the features specs needed for such a providefn and withXxx functions, it could be my very first contribution on angular :smile: (plus I could also open PRs on third-party libs like ngx-translate to make the withXxx functions)


### Proposed solution

Like I said above, a `provideTranslation` function with, for example a `locale` and `localeData` arguments.

In addition add a `...transaltionFeatures: TranslationFeature[]` to let third-party libraries maker create their `withXxx` functions to configure their lib (like `withNgxTranslate` for example)

### Alternatives considered

Instead of the first two arguments we could pass an object of options in wich we could either :
- add the locale / localeData
- or an autoDetect `boolean` option
- or even a factory to provide locales based on a specific logic
- or anything else I could not think of
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add a `provideTranslation` function to the framework (plus add a guideline to create `withXxx` features from third-party libs like ngx-translate" (#51264)

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>prettier/eslint-config-prettier (eslint-config-prettier)</summary>

### [`v9.0.0`](https://togithub.com/prettier/eslint-config-prettier/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#Version-900-2023-08-05)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/prettier/eslint-config-prettier/compare/v8.10.0...v9.0.0)

-   Added: The CLI helper tool now works with eslint.config.js (flat config). Just like ESLint itself, the CLI tool automatically first tries eslint.config.js and then eslintrc, and you can force which one to use by setting the \[ESLINT_USE_FLAT_CONFIG] environment variable. Note that the *config* of eslint-config-prettier has always been compatible with eslint.config.js (flat config) – it was just the CLI tool that needed updating. On top of that, the docs have been updated to mention how to use both eslint.config.js (flat config) and eslintrc, and the tests now test both config systems.
-   Changed: \[unicode-bom] is no longer turned off. Prettier preserves the BOM if you have one, and does not add one if missing. It was wrong of eslint-config-prettier to disable that rule. If you get ESLint errors after upgrading, either add `"unicode-bom": "off"` to your config to disable it again, or run ESLint with `--fix` to fix all files according to the rule (add or remove BOM). Thanks to Nicolas Stepien ([@​nstepien](https://togithub.com/nstepien))!

</details>

Issues.Title: styleIncludePath not resolving SCSS files in Angular Library
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

12.1.3

### Description

In a past Angular project (Angular 12) I could `@use` a SCSS file from a root folder in Angular libraries using the format:

```
@use 'sass-utils/cssvars' as *
```

In a new project I created using Angular 16, this is no longer resolved. I found a previous bug referenced [here](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/24691) that explained that the solution was to add a `styleIncludePath` property to the `ng-package.json` file, but that did not solve the issue.

### Minimal Reproduction

- ng new my-app
- cd my-app
- ng g library common
- mkdir sass-utils #this is created in root directory
- cd sass-utils
- mkdir cssvars

Create a SCSS file in the cssvars folder named `_index.scss` and attempt to `@use` it in the common library.

In addition, add the following `styleIncludePath` property in the `ng-package.json` file for the `common` library

```
"lib": {
  "entryFile": "src/public-api.ts",
  "styleIncludePaths": ["../../sass-utils"]
}
```

### Exception or Error

```text
$ ng build common
Building Angular Package

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Building entry point 'common'
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
✖ Compiling with Angular sources in Ivy partial compilation mode.
Can't find stylesheet to import.
  ╷
1 │ @use "sass-utils/cssvars" as *;
  │ ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  ╵
  test/test.component.scss 1:1  root stylesheet
```
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 16.1.8
Node: 16.16.0
Package Manager: npm 8.11.0
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 16.1.8
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1601.8
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.1.8
@angular-devkit/core            16.1.8
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.1.8
@schematics/angular             16.1.8
ng-packagr                      16.1.0
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.1.6
zone.js                         0.13.1
```

### Description

In a past Angular project (Angular 12) I could `@use` a SCSS file from a root folder in Angular libraries using the format:

@use 'sass-utils/cssvars' as *

Issues.Title: bug: running "external" schematics in yarn pnp workspace
Issues.Body:
I'm finally getting around to moving a library project that uses `@schematics/angular` to use PnP, and discovered an issue with some code in the `NodeModulesEngineHost` within `@angular-devkit/schematics`.  From my code, within a unit test, we're using the `SchematicTestRunner`'s `runExternalSchematic` function to generate a test project.  Running that function from within a pnp environment is throwing the following error:

```bash
 ENOTDIR: not a directory, lstat '/node_modules/@schematics/angular/collection.json/package.json'

      21005 |
      21006 | function makeError$1(code, message) {
    > 21007 |   return Object.assign(new Error(`${code}: ${message}`), { code });
            |                        ^
      21008 | }
      21009 | function EBUSY(message) {
      21010 |   return makeError$1(`EBUSY`, message);

      at makeError$1 (../../.pnp.cjs:21007:24)
      at ENOTDIR (../../.pnp.cjs:21025:10)
      at ZipFS.resolveFilename (../../.pnp.cjs:22607:15)
      at ZipFS.realpathSync (../../.pnp.cjs:22398:28)
      at ../../.pnp.cjs:23704:100
      at ../../.pnp.cjs:24200:60
      at ZipOpenFS.getZipSync (../../.pnp.cjs:24329:14)
      at ZipOpenFS.makeCallSync (../../.pnp.cjs:24200:17)
      at ZipOpenFS.realpathSync (../../.pnp.cjs:23696:17)
      at VirtualFS.realpathSync (../../.pnp.cjs:23446:26)
      at PosixFS.realpathSync (../../.pnp.cjs:23197:41)
      at NodePathFS.realpathSync (../../.pnp.cjs:23197:41)
      at maybeRealpathSync (../../.yarn/cache/resolve-patch-6d2631dc64-66cc788f13.zip/node_modules/resolve/lib/sync.js:52:16)
      at resolveSync (../../.yarn/cache/resolve-patch-6d2631dc64-66cc788f13.zip/node_modules/resolve/lib/sync.js:97:25)
      at NodeModulesTestEngineHost.resolve (../angular_devkit/schematics/tools/node-module-engine-host.ts:61:39)
      at NodeModulesTestEngineHost.resolve (../angular_devkit/schematics/tools/node-module-engine-host.ts:68:29)
      at createTestCaseSetup (schematics/test-utils.ts:117:40)

```

This code seems to be improperly joining the `collection.json` path and the `package.json` path (/node_modules/@schematics/angular/collection.json/package.json): https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/c34bbb8dad26aca180c2f9f4e1a6ecc5c28dd3c0/packages/angular_devkit/schematics/tools/node-module-engine-host.ts#L61 and yarn doesn't know what to do with that.  

This is the code we're running within our test:
```ts
const workspaceTree = await runner.runExternalSchematic(
    '@schematics/angular',
    'workspace',
    {
      name: 'workspace',
      version: '7.0.0',
      newProjectRoot: 'projects',
    },
    tree
  );
```

It seems that the code is trying to blindly grab that path, knowing that this case will fail and hit the catch block, since it then tries an alternative approach just after that.  So, my guess is where it's checking the error type, to decide whether to absorb the error or re-throw, it needs to consider this error type too (`ENOTDIR`)?
https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/c34bbb8dad26aca180c2f9f4e1a6ecc5c28dd3c0/packages/angular_devkit/schematics/tools/node-module-engine-host.ts#L69-L73

Seeing as this code isn't in the test-specific class, I suspect (but haven't verified) this might also fail for the `@angular-devkit/schematics` `externalSchematics` function.

Reproduction Repo: https://github.com/michaelfaith/ng-schematics-yarn-pnp-bug

_Originally posted by @michaelfaith in https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/16980#issuecomment-1640917890_
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug: running "external" schematics in yarn pnp workspace" (#25648)

Issues.Title: error: Module "mymodule" has no exported member "mycomponent"  after upgrading to angular 16
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core, Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

Yes

### Description

i am using an angular workspace with a blend of applications and libraries of my own which are used by these applications. My workspace configuration/structure is the same since i started the project with angular 10 (some changes along the way at each upgrade but nothing major).

but today after migrating to 16, one and only of my libraries failed to be imported in my application, the other libraries are imported just fine. I can't find any differences in the way they are configured though, particularly in angular.json.

this is how it is imported :  `import { DesignerComponent } from 'process'; `
I get the error below.

If I import it like this :  
`import { DesignerComponent } from '../../../../../process/src/lib/designer/designer.component';`

then it compiles just fine

### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true
error TS2305: Module '"process
"' has no exported member 'DesignerComponent'.

15 import { DesignerComponent } from 'process';
```


### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true
Angular CLI: 16.1.7
Node: 16.16.0
Package Manager: npm 8.11.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 16.1.8
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): reduce source map resolution…
Issues.Body:
… to word boundary

magic-string 0.30.2 introduced [the `boundary` strategy][1] for its high-resolution source map mode, reducing the number of source map segments to align with word boundaries instead of having a segment per character.

[1]: https://github.com/Rich-Harris/magic-string/pull/255


---
Targeting major since magic-string has only been updated to 0.30.2 on the main branch, not the rc branch.

Issues.Title: Support unit test selection in the `ng new` configuration
Issues.Body:
### Command

new, test

### Description

CLI should have a configuration option to specify the unit test runner.

Currently, even though the Jest support is still experimental, there is hardly any guidance on how to quickly spin up a jest-driven app. The available resources differ in that one recommends `"builder": "@angular-builders/jest:run"` and another `"builder": "@angular-devkit/build-angular:jest"`.

The latter, even though it is suggested by IDE:

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/681956/ca4cce96-b163-418c-bc86-5773ac6e737a)

doesn't seem to validate against the JSON schema:

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/681956/602d3591-4809-43db-a60b-3c702953634c)

unless you accept the autocomplete item which includes double `@` sign, but then it results in:

![image](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/681956/10b63334-e6a7-455b-93ec-3d8d60e41d6d)

There is of course some additional package installation and uninstallation going on, as well as ts.config massaging.
And the only way for me to have console free of warnings:

`warning: unable to locate custom jest configuration file at path "/........./jest.config.js"`

was to create an empty jest.config.js file (probably has to do with [this issue](https://github.com/just-jeb/angular-builders/issues/84)).

All in all, as you see, DX is not great, hits developer with a lot of confusion, takes a lot of manual work. Therefore having a "factory recommended" solution in place would be a great time-saver.


### Describe the solution you'd like

- add a `ng new` flag `--unit-test=karma|jest`
- add a `ng new` prompt (radio buttons) - with `(experimental)` hint for the user until the feature becomes stable
- add a schematic to convert karma to jest for the existing karma-driven projects 
- add docs obviously
- bonus: add a Stackblitz template for an angular app with jest

### Describe alternatives you've considered

need to do everything manually
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Support unit test selection in the `ng new` configuration" (#25642)

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): move TypeScript diagnostic conversion into compilation base
Issues.Body: When using the esbuild-based browser application builder, TypeScript diagnostics are now converted into esbuild messages within the compilation base class instead of the plugin. This helps further isolate the TypeScript details within the compilation classes. Additionally, this provides diagnostic objects that can be more easily serialized earlier in the build process.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(@angular-devkit/build-angular): move TypeScript diagnostic conversion into compilation base" (#25640)

## What is the new behavior?

`import` the ESM version of Vite. Vite will soon be deprecating or removing the CJS build

Angular CLI should probably be published as ESM. That will almost certainly be necessary in the long-term as more an more packages switch to ESM only. Such a change would be invisible to users since the `engines` field already specifies compatible versions of Node. Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): conditionally enable deprecated Less stylesheet JavaScript support
Issues.Body:
When a Less stylesheet is detected to require the deprecated `javascriptEnabled` Less option, the option is enabled for the stylesheet and a warning is issued to inform the user of the behavior change. The Less `javascriptEnabled` option has been deprecated and disabled by default since Less v3 (https://github.com/less/less.js/releases/tag/v3.0.0). When enabled, the `javascriptEnabled` option allows JavaScript within Less stylesheets to be executed at build time.

Less option reference: https://lesscss.org/usage/#less-options

This provides similar behavior to the default Webpack-based build system. However, the Webpack-based build system currently unconditionally enables the option.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): conditionally enable deprecated Less stylesheet JavaScript support" (#25639)

Issues.Title: fix(material/slider): Move unthemable tokens to theme mixin
Issues.Body:
Though these tokens are not currently affected by the theme, in the future they will be affected by the design system used for theming (M2 or M3)

BREAKING CHANGE:
There are new styles emitted by `mat.slider-theme` that are not emitted by any of: `mat.slider-color`, `mat.slider-typography`, `mat.slider-density`. If you rely on the partial mixins only and don't call `mat.slider-theme`, you can add `mat.slider-base` to get the missing styles.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(material/slider): Move unthemable tokens to theme mixin" (#27584)

Issues.Title: bug(dialog): document has RTL but dialog rendering LTR
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Angular dialog opened with LTR even thought the document is mentioned as RTL.
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/106318318/c0dc72ac-c63c-4003-ab29-4ab4ebd7fb45)


### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/hg55pw
Steps to reproduce:
1. default app will render with RTL direction
2. click on 'Pick one' button and the popup is render with LTR direction.

Step 1:
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/106318318/4c91dcb7-e04c-4cf1-891a-8e257464285b)

Step 2:
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/106318318/fe09db11-a27a-482c-8cc3-a51a9303513b)


### Expected Behavior

Dialog should render with RTL direction.

### Actual Behavior

Dialog should render with LTR direction.

### Environment

- Angular: 16
- CDK/Material: 16
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(dialog): document has RTL but dialog rendering LTR" (#27592)

Issues.Body:

Issues.Title: feat(list): Introducing a Description List Component
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description ## Description As an avid user and developer of Angular Material, I have come across a common scenario where I need to display detailed information, such as product characteristics, in a more visually appealing and user-friendly manner. Currently, the available mat-list component has some limitations, particularly when dealing with longer descriptions and on mobile devices. To address these issues and enhance the overall user experience, I propose the development of a new "Description List" component for Angular Material. ## Feature Overview The Description List component will aim to simplify the display of descriptive information, especially when dealing with lengthy content. It will provide the following key features to cater to different screen sizes and use cases: - **Unrestricted Height on Mobile** On mobile devices, the Description List component will be designed to occupy the available vertical space without any height limitation. This will ensure that users can view all the content without any truncation or text ellipsis, offering a seamless browsing experience on smaller screens. - **Responsive Design** The Description List component will be responsive to adapt to different screen sizes and orientations. On mobile devices, it will provide an intuitive and easy-to-read layout, while on desktops or larger screens, it will take advantage of the additional space by displaying terms and descriptions side by side. - **Flexibility in Content Display** The Description List component will allow users to input varying lengths of labels and descriptions. It will dynamically adjust the layout based on the content's length, ensuring that information is presented in a visually appealing manner while maintaining readability. ### Use Case Introducing the Description List component will offer several benefits to developers and end-users: - **Enhanced User Experience** By providing an improved and responsive display for lengthy descriptive information, users can easily comprehend product characteristics and other details without any truncation or clutter. - **Consistency with Angular Material** The new component will seamlessly integrate into the existing Angular Material ecosystem, maintaining the consistent and professional look and feel users have come to expect. - **Reduced Development Efforts** Developers will save time and effort by utilizing this out-of-the-box component for displaying detailed information, rather than resorting to custom solutions or third-party libraries. - **Mobile-Friendly** With unrestricted height on mobile devices, the Description List component will cater to an increasing number of users accessing applications on their smartphones and tablets. ### Implementation Ideas The Description List component can be implemented by creating a new Angular Material module that includes the necessary CSS styles and layout logic or use the current `MatListModule`. It can leverage Angular's flexbox and grid systems to achieve the responsive layout and dynamic adjustments based on the content's length. #### Code Example (Potential Usage): ```html Product Name: Super Amazing Product Product Code: ABC123
Product Name:
Super Amazing Product
Product Code:
ABC123
Product Name:
Super Amazing Product
Product Code:
ABC123
``` ### Conclusion The introduction of the Description List component to Angular Material will significantly improve the display of descriptive information, particularly in scenarios with lengthy product characteristics or similar content. The component's responsiveness and flexibility will ensure an optimal user experience across different devices, making it a valuable addition to the Angular Material library. Thank you for considering this feature request. I believe that this enhancement will greatly benefit the Angular Material community and contribute to a more robust and user-friendly UI framework. I look forward to seeing this feature become a reality :). Thank you for all your efforts.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(list): Introducing a Description List Component" (#27591)

Fixes #27508.

Issues.Title: fix(youtube-player): Allow playlists without specifying videoId (#27529)
Issues.Body:
When using a YouTube Player, it is possible to specify a playlist without specifying a videoId. This is useful when you want to play a playlist and don't have a VideoId.

Previously, the player would not initialise if a VideoId wasn't specified but a Playlist was specified, even though the YouTube API supports this use case.

This commit adds support for this use case.

Fix #27529
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(youtube-player): Allow playlists without specifying videoId (#27529)" (#27588)

Issues.Title: List item sanity check uses wrong variable
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

I guess never

### Description

In the sanity check of the list item base class there is the variable `numLines` which instead of using the number of lines actually uses the number of titles accidentally. You can see this here: https://github.com/angular/components/blob/03a773a0237843fd1e1e600d0b9911eb924319bc/src/material/list/list-base.ts#L329C9-L329C18

`_titles` must be replaced by `_lines`.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ex442q?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.html,src%2Fapp%2Fapp.module.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. Just see the HTML, it adds 4 list item lines
2. The sanity check usually should forbid more than 3 lines
3. But as it uses the title count for the check, it still works


### Expected Behavior

Use the number of lines instead of titles.
Number of lines is limited to 3.

### Actual Behavior

Uses the number of titles for the line count check.
Number of lines is not limited.

### Environment

- Angular: any
- CDK/Material: any
- Browser(s): any
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): any
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "List item sanity check uses wrong variable" (#27582)

Issues.Title: bug(datepicker): Duplicate marker on calendar pop up when inputting date that is outwith min/max dates
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

I have set the min and max dates using their respective properties. When I type in a date that is after the max date, and then open the calendar, a marker appears on both the date I typed in and the max date. This behaviour could arguably be slightly confusing to the user but it is particularly misleading in the instance that the highlighted max date is actually disabled due to custom validation. The same issue can be seen for the minimum date.
![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/71448881/a2f4c43d-61f4-4ee1-be13-9cd381d7e33f)


### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/run?file=package.json (an example from the docs)
Steps to reproduce:
1. In datepicker-min-max-example.ts, adjust the max date so that it is not the last day of the month (so that the issue can be seen) e.g. change it to the 15th
2. In the input, type in a date which is after the max date - e.g. the 18th
3. Open the calendar and you will see that two dates are highlighted - the date that was typed in and the maximum date.
4. Provide a custom validator that would render the maximum date disabled e.g. if the max date was a Sunday but weekends are not allowed. Repeat steps 2 & 3 and you will see that this date is highlighted even though it is invalid.
5. Same steps for minimum date.

### Expected Behavior

I am expecting to see only one date highlighted on the calendar - just the (invalid one) that was typed in. If this is not desired, then it should still take into account other invalid/disabled dates through customer validator, so it should highlight the maximum valid date rather than the general maximum date regardless of its validity. Likewise for the minimum date.

### Actual Behavior

I saw two dates highlighted on the calendar - the date I typed in and the maximum date. The maximum date is also highlighted even when it has been rendered invalid by a custom validator, which could be misleading to users - this is the main issue. Likewise for the minimum date.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.1.6
- CDK/Material: 16.1.6
- Browser(s): Google Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(datepicker): Duplicate marker on calendar pop up when inputting date that is outwith min/max dates" (#27573)

Issues.Title: fix(material/autocomplete): don't assign to model value while typing when requireSelection is enabled
Issues.Body:
Follow-up to #27423 based on the feedback. Usually `mat-autocomplete` assigns to the model as the user is typing which may not be desired when `requireSelection` is enabled, because at the end of the selection either an option value will set or it'll be reset.

These changes add a condition so that the value isn't assigned while typing and `requireSelection` is enabled.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(material/autocomplete): don't assign to model value while typing when requireSelection is enabled" (#27572)
